What is the Hedera Local Node project for?

The Hedera Local Node project enables developers to establish their own local network for development and testing. It comprises the consensus node, mirror node, JSON-RPC relay, and other Hedera products, and can be set up using the CLI tool and Docker.

What are the prerequisites for setting up a Hedera Local Node?

The prerequisites for setting up a Hedera Local Node include having Node.js and NPM installed, a minimum of 16GB RAM, Docker and Docker Compose installed, and Docker running on your machine with the correct configurations.

How can I start a local node for Hedera using Docker?
To start a local node with Docker, you can run the command 'hedera start -d' in your terminal, ensuring that Docker is installed and open on your machine.

How can I generate accounts with random private keys for the local node?

You can generate accounts with random private keys by running the command 'hedera generate-accounts' followed by the number of accounts you want to generate, for example, 'hedera generate-accounts 5'.

How can I stop the local node for Hedera?
You can stop the local node by running the command 'hedera stop' to stop and remove the Docker container volumes and clean the manually generated files.

What should I do if I want to keep any manually created files in the working directory when stopping the local node?
If you want to keep any manually created files in the working directory when stopping the local node, you should save them before executing the 'hedera stop' command.

The steps involved in setting up a Hedera Local Node include cloning the repository, installing dependencies, starting the local node, generating keys, and stopping the local node.

What configurations are required for Docker in the local node setup?
The required configurations for Docker in the local node setup include setting CPUs to 6, Memory to 8GB, Swap to 1 GB, and Disk Image Size to 64 GB.

How can I run the Hedera Local Node if I'm a Windows user?
If you're a Windows user, you will need to update the file endings of 'compose-network/mirror-node/init.sh' by running a command in WSL using 'dos2unix'.

What private key from the generated accounts can be used as the environment variable value in the '.env' file of a project?
You can use any of the private keys generated from the 'Alias ECDSA keys Accounts list' as the 'LOCAL_NODE_OPERATOR_PRIVATE_KEY' environment variable value in your '.env' file of your project.
